column1: My first visit was to the largest hall in Warsaw
column3: where the large Philharmonic concerts are usually held and which in ordinary times is the gathering place of society. It is now converted into a refuge for 600 or 700 homeless fugitives
column4: who have left their all behind them and fled in terror
column7: and carrying their possessions on their backs. The majority are old men
column9: and children. In the babel of voices are frequently heard pitiful cries of poorly fed children
column11: and groans and wailings of mothers who still seem stunned and stupefied by their frightful experiences.Dinner was being served when I arrived. At several tables sat women
column14: while men were being served in one of the large corridors. Standing in endless rows
column15: they took their turn at the steaming pots. In the main hall many fugitives were crouching on the floor
column17: and piled about them were little mounds of household effects that they had succeeded in saving from their wrecked and ruined homes.
